Something that I think you should expand on is the misinformation regarding virus size (physical dimensions), and mask filtration effectiveness. There is a belief by some that masks are completely ineffective against viruses because viruses are too small to filter which is actually true, but misleading, because viruses by themselves can't survive long in the open environment anyway. They actually survive airborne transmission from host to host absorbed inside droplets of moisture, spittle, or flem which partially protects and shields enough of these viruses from environmental variables like UV light. As long as some viruses survive the trip absorbed into one of these moisture particles, they can still successfully transmit between hosts. So mask filtration doesn't necessarily need to be extreme enough to capture and stop something as small as a virus in order to be effective. It only needs to filter the airborne particles that are harboring viruses.

It's been explained many times why the basic premise here is wrong:

There are NO randomized, controlled trials (RCT) with verified outcomes that show a benefit to healthcare workers or community members for wearing a mask or a respirator. There is no such definitive study. Likewise, no study exists that shows a benefit from a broad policy to wear masks in public.

Furthermore, if there were any benefits to wearing a mask, because of the blocking power against droplets and aerosol particles, then there should be more benefit from wearing a respirator (N95) compared to a surgical mask. There is not. Neither masks nor respirators protect; cloth coverings are essentially worthless.

It should be noted that the surgical masks are primarily designed to protect the environment from the wearer, whereas the respirators are supposed to protect the wearer from the environment.

Coronavirus are <0.125 microns in size. Masks and respirators filter particles 0.30 to 0.80 microns in size. Masks cannot possibly work. No bias-free study has ever found a benefit from wearing a mask or respirator in this application.

Also let's not forget that we're speaking of exponential growth, not linear growth. If everybody wore a 50% effective mask this would mean every individual would effectively have a quarter of their expected infections per individual factored into the exponential growth formula for covid. Let's take an example formula for exponential growth where we take 100*e^3 which equals about 2008. Now we apply the 75% reduction to the exponent and find that 100*e^0.75 equals only 212 which is only about 10% of the original value before we applied our 75% reduction. Now obviously this isn't the exact formula for covid's expected spread, but this very clearly showcases the sheer power of attacking the exponent in an exponential growth curve, making masks and social distancing all the more effective the more people keep doing it. Added to this if we manage to get our exponent <1 in exponential growth this means we're actually on the decline rather than growth.

and somehow you skipped over the exponential growth of the virus altogether, even though that's the biggest issue at play here by a lot. So lets say wearing a mask reduces the transmission rate by 50%. Lets say everyone wears a mask. Now, only half as many people are infected by the people who have it now. So in 1 generation the number infected halves, but here comes the interesting part.

Now you have half as many people spreading the disease. So the next generation you have 1/4 as many infected, because half as many people are spreading the disease at half the rate. In the next generation you now have 1/4 as many people infecting half as many people each, or 1/8th the infected. 1/16th, 1/32, 1/64th, etc. etc So after just ~8 weeks/2 months you now have 1/254th as many people infected as you would if it spread uncontrolled, and that difference will just continue to compound with every generation.

What's worse, it's operating under the assumption that masks worn by one individual but not the other individual actually results in a noticeable reduction.

If you actually do the math, the data just doesn't support this. Studies have shown that your average cloth mask prevents something like 90% of the viral particles from passing *directly through the material*. This is with a literal airtight seal around the edges of the cloth, which obviously isn't even close to the case in reality. Still, let's proceed using that 90% number to be super generous. Note that this number is for your typical cloth mask, not a proper n95 with a good seal. Those were shown to provide orders of magnitude greater protection, stopping upwards of 99.9% of particles.

Studies done on hospitalized patients suffering from influenza have shown that there is an average of 8000 viral particles suspended in the air of their hospital rooms per liter of air. Assuming COVID-19 is similar (which seems reasonable, given that researchers have used influenza as a stand in for covid) then let's take that number. The average human breathes in roughly 10 liters of air per minute. Without anyone wearing a mask, then it is logical to assume that on average our poor test subjects would be breathing in an average of 64,000 viral particles per minute in the presence of an infected individual.

Estimates vary, but most seem to place an infectious dose (how many particles is required to create an infection) somewhere between the low hundreds to the low thousands (I've seen anywhere from 200 particles to 5000 particles quoted). So, needless to say.. without masks, it's easy to see how the disease spreads easily.

Let's put a mask on the infected individual and try this again. Now, we've filtered out 90% of the outgoing particles. Instead of 8000 particles per liter, there's now 800. Our unmasked test subject enters the room and hangs out for a minute. They'll leave having breathed in 8000 viral particles in just that single minute. Again, well above the highest estimates for an infectious dose. Putting a mask on just the infected individual didn't really cut the transmission rate much, simply because the amount of outgoing particles is just utter overkill compared to the rather tiny infectious dose.

So, let's put a mask on both the patient and the test subject. There's 800 particles per liter of air, but only 80 are being breathed in. After a minute the subject has breathed in 800 particles. That's lower than the high estimates of an infectious dose to be sure, but well above the low estimates - and that's with only a single minute of exposure.

Keeping in mind that real world performance of masks would be significantly worse than the airtight seals seen in the lab setting for purposes of testing the cloth itself, and the fact that many people would utterly invalidate any protection given by a mask simply by failing to wash their hands after coming in contact with a contaminated surface.. well, masks work a lot WORSE than what most people actually think. They're effective, but only if absolutely everyone wears them, and even then only for extremely brief exposures. They simply won't be effective from stopping students sitting in a classroom from infecting the other students, or preventing coworkers working in the same room with one another for extended periods of time from infecting one another. Yet these are the very sorts of situations where our government officials are encouraging citizens to rely on masks to be effective, all the while encouraging businesses and schools to reopen.

This is more or less exactly what we see given the spread rate of the disease too. In the initial months of the pandemic almost everyone in my area was wearing masks after it was mandated that we do so, and I'm from an extremely conservative region of my state - exactly the sort that are least likely to abide by such regulations. Yet, despite all that, the spread rate remained essentially unchanged. There was no drastic reduction.. and in September, when schools reopened and restrictions on businesses began to be relaxed, there was a massive increase in the spread rate (we're now up to 10x what was seen in those earlier months). The overwhelming majority of people are wearing masks (I generally see maybe 5% or less not wearing them in my area) - but they're simply not stemming the tide. That's exactly what I'd expect if they had effectively no impact, and not at all what I'd expect if they worked as advertised.

We should absolutely be wearing them - for brief potential exposures. For long term exposures to other people though, there's essentially no point. We should be limiting such exposures as much as possible using other more effective methods, and when such exposures are simply unavoidable (such as coworkers working in an essential job that demands they work together closely) we shouldn't be mandating mask usage when it really won't have any impact beyond such a short exposure window. It's not logical or reasonable, and it encourages people to rely on a masks to provide a level of protection that they simply are not capable of providing.

Your math doesn't seem to account for the likelihood of a given interaction containing COVID.
The lower the general transmission rate, the lower the chance that a given interaction has COVID there to pass along.
Meaning that the overall population transmission should be lower than the individual transmission rate... I think.
Especially since you can't tell if you have it (and thus alter your behavior) until long after you've been spreading it.

Like: If 1 in 10 people has COVID to pass along, then a healthy person has a 10% chance of the interaction being with COVID.
And the mask would cut the chance of catching COVID to a 2.5% chance, yeah?

But if the masks have cut the transmission to 2.5% overall, then a given interaction has a 2.5% chance of being with COVID
and thus a 0.625% (?) chance of the healthy person catching COVID. Which is way better than a 75% drop.

Unless I'm misunderstanding how this works? Obviously it's not that simple because the population already has a certain percentage of cases, and it takes time for the mask measures to change that, but I think this model makes sense.

Also: Apparently they've compared some groups with masks to groups with no masks and found that the dose you get matters, not so much about whether or not you get COVID but whether you develop noticeable symptoms (let alone severe symptoms). So cutting down on the amount you get is good regardless.

2020: A review of the literature that was published in the CDC journal Emerging Infectious Diseases did not find evidence that masks were protective against influenza. Masks did not help infected people reduce their risk of infecting others, nor reduce the risk of uninfected people contracting influenza:
‘In this review, we did not find evidence to support a protective effect of personal protective measures or environmental measures in reducing influenza transmission..We did not find evidence that surgical-type face masks are effective in reducing laboratory-confirmed influenza transmission, either when worn by infected persons (source control) or by persons in the general community to reduce their susceptibility’.
They also admitted that ‘the mechanisms of person-to-person transmission in the community have not been fully determined. Controversy remains over the role of transmission through fine-particle aerosols. Transmission by indirect contact requires transfer of viable virus from respiratory mucosa onto hands and other surfaces, survival on those surfaces, and successful inoculation into the respiratory mucosa of another person. All of these components of the transmission route have not been studied extensively.’

2020: Two studies (here and here) suggests that in some cases the virus can enter the brain, potentially via the olfactory nerves and connect directly with the area of the brain dealing with recent memory and memory consolidation. Through wearing a mask, the exhaled viruses will not be able to escape and will concentrate in the nasal passages, which may lead to them being able to enter the olfactory nerves and travel into the brain.

2020: This study looked whether there was shedding of fibres from disposable and reusable masks. Research on synthetic fibres has shown a correlation between the inhalation of synthetic fibres and various bronchopulmonary diseases, such as asthma, alveolitis, chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, fibrosis, COPD, spontaneous pneumothorax and chronic pneumonia. They posit that it may also cause Pulmonary fibrosis which they claim ‘is among the worst diseases that can be suffered or witnessed. It kills exceedingly slowly, by ever-thickening matrix formation, a kind of scar tissue, obstructing the alveoli and reducing their air exchange. The illness worsens slowly over time, and suffocates the victim very gradually. Nothing is available to the sufferer from conventional medicine. Neither medication nor radiation can undo the damage of the fibrous matrix laid down in the lungs’ tissue. Similarly, surgery is not available to eliminate the insidious, suffocating mesh that painstakingly takes the life of the unfortunate patient. Neither is any known cure available in the realm of natural or alternative medicine. Neither nutrient, herb, nor any other known treatment can even reduce the fibrogenesis, let alone eliminate it. The 5-year survival rate is only 20%. The only remedy against this scourge is diligent prevention of small and microscopic inhaled foreign bodies.’

2020: This working paper focused on 25 U.S. states and 23 countries with more than 1,000 Covid-19 deaths (as of late July). They concluded that the data trends observed likely indicate that non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) – such as lockdowns, closures, travel restrictions, stay-home orders, event bans, quarantines, curfews, and mask mandates – do not seem to affect virus transmission rates overall.

2020: This small scale study analysed 14 masks and coverings by using a tool that allowed researchers to track individual particles released from a person's mouth when they spoke the phrase “Stay healthy, people.” Speakers said the same phrase while wearing the different models of masks, and no masks at all, to compare. Each face covering was tested 10 times.
“The neck gaiter that we tested did essentially nothing, and worse than nothing, because it appeared to make large droplets into small droplets,” Isaac Henrion, the study's co-author, told CBS News. The experiment involved only a small number of speakers and face coverings, and the researchers stressed that more testing is needed - some gaiters might work better than others, depending on how they're made.

2020: The New England Journal of Medicine editorial on the topic of mask use versus Covid-19 assesses the matter as follows:
‘We know that wearing a mask outside health care facilities offers little, if any, protection from infection. Public health authorities define a significant exposure to Covid-19 as face-to-face contact within 6 feet with a patient with symptomatic Covid-19 that is sustained for at least a few minutes (and some say more than 10 minutes or even 20 minutes). The chance of catching Covid-19 from a passing interaction in a public space is therefore minimal. In many cases, the desire for widespread masking is a reflexive reaction to anxiety over the pandemic.’

2020: This study found that 624 out of 714 people wearing N95 masks left visible gaps when putting on their own masks. Of participants given N95 respirators with an instruction sheet and then asked to put one on, only about 13% passed the visual mask fit test.

2020: This review found that masks had no effect specifically against Covid-19, although facemask use seemed linked to, in 3 of 31 studies, ‘very slightly reduced’ odds of developing influenza-like illness.

2020: Plastic face shields are almost totally ineffective at trapping respiratory aerosols, according to modelling in Japan. A simulation using Fugaku, the world’s fastest supercomputer, found that almost 100% of airborne droplets of less than 5 micrometres in size escaped through plastic visors of the kind often used by people working in service industries.

2020: This CDC study, which surveyed symptomatic Covid-19 patients, has found that 70.6% of respondents reported ‘always’ wearing a mask, while an additional 14.4% say they ‘often’ wear a mask. That means 85% of infected Covid-19 patients reported habitual mask wearing. Only 3.9% of those infected said they ‘never’ wear a face covering.

2019: This randomised clinical trial of 2862 participants showed that both N95 respirators and surgical masks ‘resulted in no significant difference in the incidence of laboratory confirmed influenza.’

2018: This study shows a potential causation link between hypoxia and blood clotting and discovered that hypoxia down regulates expression of the important natural anticoagulant protein S. The level

2018: This study shows a potential causation link between hypoxia and blood clotting and discovered that hypoxia down regulates expression of the important natural anticoagulant protein S. The level of protein S was found to drop by 50% when O2 levels were at 15%.
An N95 mask simulates a similarly low oxygen saturation, which could indicate that wearing a mask may decrease your natural ability to prevent blood clots by 50%.

2018: This study provides strong evidence for the identification that surgical masks are as source of bacterial contamination during operative procedures. It recommends surgeons should change their mask after each operation, especially those beyond 2 hours.

2018: This study looked at whether wearing a mask affected the Six Minutes Walking Test (6MWT) which is regularly used in pulmonology. They found that surgical mask wearers had significantly increased dyspnea (difficult or laboured breathing) after a 6-minute walk than non-mask wearers.

2016: A review of current research written from the perspective of the dental professional notes:
‘The primary reason for mandating the wearing of face masks is to protect dental personnel from airborne pathogens. This review has established that face masks are incapable of providing such a level of protection. Unless the CDC, national and provincial dental associations and regulatory agencies publically admit this fact, they will be guilty of perpetuating a myth which will be a disservice to the dental profession and its patients.’

2016: An article in The Journal of Biological Engineering notes that: ‘Wearing respirators come[s] with a host of physiological and psychological burdens. These can interfere with task performances and reduce work efficiency. These burdens can even be severe enough to cause life-threatening conditions if not ameliorated.’

2016: This meta-analysis found that both randomised controlled trials and observational studies of N95 respirators and surgical masks used by healthcare workers did not show benefit against transmission of acute respiratory infections. It was also found that acute respiratory infection transmission ‘may have occurred via contamination of provided respiratory protective equipment during storage and reuse of masks and respirators throughout the workday.’

2015: This study claimed to be the first randomised control trial of cloth masks and ‘the results caution against the use of cloth masks. This is an important finding to inform occupational health and safety. Moisture retention, reuse of cloth masks and poor filtration may result in increased risk of infection. Further research is needed to inform the widespread use of cloth masks globally.’

2015: This study claimed to be the first randomised control trial of cloth masks and ‘the results caution against the use of cloth masks. This is an important finding to inform occupational health and safety. Moisture retention, reuse of cloth masks and poor filtration may result in increased risk of infection. Further research is needed to inform the widespread use of cloth masks globally.’

2015: A study in the British Medical Journal found that healthcare workers caught viruses from their patients 13 times more often if they wore a cloth mask than if they wore a medical mask.

While I agree with this principle, and the mathematics; is there any studies showing how masks increase the amount that people touch their face? (Possible transmission vector through cracks in the skin, or eye contact; or possibly contaminating the skin surface) Or that the mask can become a contaminated surface, allowing for a new possible transmission vector to the virus? (I.e. a sick person wearing a mask touches their mask, then other surfaces; or in turn a non sick person wearing a mask touches their mask contaminating their hands and then touching surfaces, etc.). What about people wearing masks thinking they are safe and participating in more high risk activities, neglecting hand sanitation, and avoiding social distancing? (The Peltzman effect).  What about masks that are discarded and are now a biohazardous waste material (possibly infecting sanitation workers or accumulating hazardous bio masses in one area)? I ask these questions sincerely and am just curious if the potential safety outweighs the risks. Thanks in advance for keeping the conversation civil.

I love your videos and the maths of disease transmission is fascinating (I was an epidemiologist). But there’s a big assumption here - that the reduction in transmission is proportional to the reduction in virus load/dose. It isn’t, it’s usually more sigmoidal, so your maths may be right if dose is in the growth phase of the dose response curve, but very wrong if in the plateau phase of the curve. It’s likely why - despite legislated mass face-mask wearing in European countries - no effective drop in transmission rate was observed upon the introduction of these measures.

The study states:

Earlier studies demonstrated the critical contribution of the amygdala to the fear circuit and fear-related behavior (Adolphs, 2002; Kim and Jung, 2006; Maren, 2008; Phelps and LeDoux, 2005; Rosen, 2004). Our results now indicate that the amygdala does more than mediate the fear response, it also has an important chemosensory role. ASIC1a channels in the amygdala detect a reduced pH arising from an increased CO2 or from direct injection of acid. That CO2 initiates a fear response is particularly intriguing because rising CO2 forewarns suffocation, a terrifying situation that demands sensitive detection and action to ensure survival. Thus, it is interesting that evolution positioned a sensor for hypercarbic acidosis in the amygdala, a structure that stimulates the sympathetic nervous system for fight-or-flight and links to other brain regions involved in the response to threat. Thus, the amygdala both senses a threat, posed by CO2, and initiates a response.

This random controlled trial on cloth masks saw them actually favour worse than controls of no mask at all. It states:

Results The rates of all infection outcomes were highest in the cloth mask arm, with the rate of ILI statistically significantly higher in the cloth mask arm (relative risk (RR)=13.00, 95% CI 1.69 to 100.07) compared with the medical mask arm. Cloth masks also had significantly higher rates of ILI compared with the control arm. An analysis by mask use showed ILI (RR=6.64, 95% CI 1.45 to 28.65) and laboratory-confirmed virus (RR=1.72, 95% CI 1.01 to 2.94) were significantly higher in the cloth masks group compared with the medical masks group. Penetration of cloth masks by particles was almost 97% and medical masks 44%.

Conclusions This study is the first RCT of cloth masks, and the results caution against the use of cloth masks. This is an important finding to inform occupational health and safety. Moisture retention, reuse of cloth masks and poor filtration may result in increased risk of infection. Further research is needed to inform the widespread use of cloth masks globally. However, as a precautionary measure, cloth masks should not be recommended for HCWs, particularly in high-risk situations, and guidelines need to be updated.

https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/5/4/e006577

In this study of studies we read why masks can be more detrimental than helpful:
Intuition would suggest that facemasks offer a physical barrier preventing the emanation of droplets from the oral or nasal passages and therefore satisfy the efficacy requirement of the evidence ladder. However, there are a number of different hypotheses as to why this may not be the case. ‘Venting’ is a phenomenon whereby air leaks at the interface between mask and face which can act to disperse potential contaminants originating from the pharynx.5 The accumulation of moisture, during prolonged usage, may exacerbate this problem by increasing resistance to air flow through the filter itself. Moisture accumulation is also thought to facilitate the movement of contaminants through the material of the mask itself by capillary action. These bacteria can subsequently be dislodged by movement. Friction at the face/mask interface has also been demonstrated to disperse skin scales which can further contribute towards wound contamination.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4480558/

In fact this study goes so far as to state that:
It has never been shown that wearing surgical face masks decreases postoperative wound infections. On the contrary, a 50% decrease has been reported after omitting face masks. The present study was designed to reveal any 30% or greater difference in general surgery wound infection rates by using face masks or not.

During 115 weeks, a total of 3,088 patients were included in the study. Weeks were denoted as “masked” or “unmasked” according to a random list. After 1,537 operations performed with face masks, 73 (4.7%) wound infections were recorded and, after 1,551 operations performed without face masks, 55 (3.5%) infections occurred. This difference was not statistically significant (p> 0.05) and the bacterial species cultured from the wound infections did not differ in any way, which would have supported the fact that the numerical difference was a statistically “missed” difference.

These results indicate that the use of face masks might be reconsidered. Masks may be used to protect the operating team from drops of infected blood and from airborne infections, but have not been proven to protect the patient operated by a healthy operating team.
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01658736

Colleen Huber NMD looks at the studies in this analysis and states:

Surgical mask wearers had significantly increased dyspnea after a 6-minute walk than non-mask wearers. (30)

Researchers are concerned about possible burden of facemasks during physical activity on pulmonary, circulatory and immune systems, due to oxygen reduction and air trapping reducing substantial carbon dioxide exchange. As a result of hypercapnia, there may be cardiac overload, renal overload, and a shift to metabolic acidosis. (31)

Risks of N95 respirators

Pregnant healthcare workers were found to have a loss in volume of oxygen consumption by 13.8% compared to controls when wearing N95 respirators. 17.7% less carbon dioxide was exhaled. (32) Patients with end-stage renal disease were studied during use of N95 respirators. Their partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) decreased significantly compared to controls and increased respiratory adverse effects. (33) 19% of the patients developed various degrees of hypoxemia while wearing the masks.

Healthcare workers’ N95 respirators were measured by personal bioaerosol samplers to harbor influenza virus. (34) And 25% of healthcare workers’ facepiece respirators were found to contain influenza in an emergency department during the 2015 flu season. (35)

Risks of surgical masks

Healthcare workers’ surgical masks also were measured by personal bioaerosol samplers to harbor for influenza virus. (36)

Various respiratory pathogens were found on the outer surface of used medical masks, which could result in self-contamination. The risk was found to be higher with longer duration of mask use. (37)

Surgical masks were also found to be a repository of bacterial contamination. The source of the bacteria was determined to be the body surface of the surgeons, rather than the operating room environment. (38) Given that surgeons are gowned from head to foot for surgery, this finding should be especially concerning for laypeople who wear masks. Without the protective garb of surgeons, laypeople generally have even more exposed body surface to serve as a source for bacteria to collect on their masks.

Masks and respirators do not work. There have been extensive randomized controlled trial (RCT) studies, and meta-analysis reviews of RCT studies, which all show that masks and respirators do not work to prevent respiratory influenza-like illnesses, or respiratory illnesses believed to be transmitted by droplets and aerosol particles. There are some big logic gaps in this analysis. 1.) The CDC states that wearing a mask provides basically no protection to the wearer, and the primary reason to promote mask wearing is to prevent you from spreading it unknowingly. This alone kills this "surprising math" since it is a one-way transmission. 2.) These kinds of models assume that transmission via droplets is the only mode of transmission. Other modes include lack of hand washing, touching ones face, etc. The percentage of prevention a mask offers only reflects a smaller percentage of all possible modes of transmission, so to say it would prevent X% is misleading. 3.) The CDC has also stated that transmission via droplets in quick, every day contact (less than 10 min) is fairly rare. They have also said that asymptomatic transmission is fairly rare as well. To paraphrase Dr. Fauci: "prolonged contact with a symptomatic person is almost always the primary driver of transmission." So masks are a good idea to wear in certain settings for sure, but are not some kind of silver bullet, and at the end of the day, only do a small part by themselves to slow the spread. The insane level of focus on wearing them, such as making them mandatory, is totally scientifically unmerited.

I wonder if similar masks have diminishing returns. For example: Person A has a 50% effectiveness mask and Person B has the same type of mask. A's mask works as intended, but, by the time the infectious particles reach B's mask, most of the particles that would be blocked by the mask have already been removed, making B's mask less effective against the remaining infectious particles.

I'm not saying this is definitely how it is, but it does seem like a reasonable enough situation to be worthy of consideration.

11) List of studies from 1981 to 2015 on the ineffectiveness of face masks to prevent infection: Neil Orr’s study, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2493952/pdf/annrcse01509-0009.pdf
published in 1981 in the Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of
England. Dr. Orr was a surgeon in the Severalls Surgical Unit in
Colchester. And for six months, from March through August 1980, the
surgical staff in that unit decided to see what would happen if they did
not wear masks during surgeries. They wore no masks for six months, and
compared the rate of surgical wound infections from March through
August 1980 with the rate of wound infections from March through August
of the previous four years. And they discovered, to their amazement,
that when nobody wore masks during surgeries, the rate of wound
infections was less than half what it was when everyone wore masks.
Conclusion: “It would appear that minimum contamination can best be
achieved by not wearing a mask at all” and that wearing a mask during
surgery “is a standard procedure that could be abandoned.”

Masks are useless in preventing the spread of disease and, if anything,
are unsanitary objects that themselves spread bacteria and viruses.
Masks get touched regularly, sneezed in, coughed in, and create sweat
and moisture which all create unnecessary contamination to be inhaled,
again and again.

In Tunevall’s 1991 study,
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01658736 a general surgical
team wore no masks in half of their surgeries for two years. After 1,537
operations performed with masks, the wound infection rate was 4.7%,
while after 1,551 operations performed without masks, the wound
infection rate was only 3.5%.

A review by Skinner and Sutton in 2001
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0310057X0102900402
concluded that “The evidence for discontinuing the use of surgical face
masks would appear to be stronger than the evidence available to support
their continued use.”

Lahme et al., in 2001, https://europepmc.org/article/med/11760479 wrote
that “surgical face masks worn by patients during regional anaesthesia,
did not reduce the concentration of airborne bacteria over the operation
field in our study.”

Figueiredo et al., in 2001,
http://www.advancesinpd.com/adv01/21Figueiredo.htm reported that in five
years of doing peritoneal dialysis without masks, rates of peritonitis
in their unit were no different.

Not to say that this isn't important information, but I think the reality of the situation is that not much of this matters at this point. People have already decided on what measures they are willing to take to reduce the spread of disease, and barring a major change in transmission numbers, they aren't going to change their minds. COVID might not be well-understood in terms of understanding all the health consequences it exposes people to, but in aggregate, the disease is low-risk enough that most people who don't take it seriously won't be punished for it, which means that they're going to continue not to take it seriously.

Like it or not, we now live in a world where COVID is part of the human pathology. The social will to eradicate it isn't there and unless a cure happens, it never will be. It isn't a pandemic anymore; it's endemic. It's at the point where it's like the flu: it's something you're sad if you get, and some people take measures to avoid it, but if you get it then you just live with it (or die with it) and that's part of human existence. We could have prevented it before, but not anymore, and humans are now ~4% likelier to die than they were before.

Looking at the pandemic curves and annotating them with the introduction of mask mandates it's hard to make the case that masks are effective at all. If two people in a social interaction are wearing 0% effective masks, the effective transmission prevention rate is still 0%. Also, real science wouldn't just assume a 50% bidirectional transmission reduction, it would measure it... in both directions. I've seen no scientific studies that verify that masks are effective at all.

What we do know about the transmission of this virus is that most transmissions occur in close contact settings, not in the community at large. So far in my county (which does contact tracing), the spread through the at-large population is 2:1 close contact versus community transmission. In the prisons and nursing homes (counted separately from the at-large community) 100% of the cases are being ascribed to close contact. Yet we know that mask wearers are most likely to let their guard down and remove their masks when among close contacts. In the early days of the pandemic before masks were mandated it was even more dramatic that most transmissions were occurring in close contact situations. If we were to go by the data collected by my county we'd have to say that mandated mask wearing is correlated with higher incidence of community transmission versus close contact transmission. (Correlation, of course, does not equal causation, but it does call into question the effectiveness of mask mandates.)

Another thing we know (pointed out by Dr Fauci himself) is that no pandemic of an infectious respiratory illness has ever been driven by asymptomatic cases. It's always those with respiratory symptoms (coughing, sneezing) that spread the disease. Staying home when you're feeling sick or having symptoms is much much more effective at halting the transmission than wearing a questionably effective mask in public.

Really, the only thing that's effective against a pandemic is herd immunity. Whether that comes through infection of relatively non-vulnerable demographics or whether it comes through a vaccine is immaterial. There is only one exit door for a pandemic... herd immunity.

Further caveats: infectious dose and viral load.

A single virus particle is not enough to make a person sick. There is a threshold that must be surpassed in order for a person to get sick. This is the infectious dose. Reducing the number of viral particles has better than a linear effect on the rate of disease transmission because doing so greatly reduces the probability of a person being exposed to an infectious dose within a given time period.

Also, the severity of a viral infection depends on the number of infectious particles in the body. This is the viral load. Reducing the number of viral particles results in less-severe infections. Aside from the obvious benefits, this also has a positive effect on the rate of disease transmission because people with a higher viral load are more contagious than people with a lower viral load.

So if you see that a certain mask is 50% effective at stopping viral particles, it actually has a greater than 50% effectiveness at reducing the rate of disease transmission.

Excellent video. However, I have seen lots of analysis of infectious disease spread that assume equal transmission between everyone. What is missing is analysis that takes into account that some people spread much more than others due to behavioral patterns (work requirements, wearing a mask or not, etc). For example a significant proportion of early spread for covid came from particular types of gatherings and health workers. This may explain why many countries saw a peak then drop that didn't necessarily line up with lockdown measures. Maybe the virus just runs out of certain types of professions/behaviors.

This is interesting. But there are a few assumptions here that have yet to be verified...
The 50% effectiveness idea for one. Empirical studies have very heterogeneous conclusions regarding effect size of wearing maks.
Second, and most importantly, while there is a lot of evidence that wearing mask when you are infected will reduce the risk of contaminating others, there is almost no (or very weak) evidence that wearing a wask, when healthy, will protect you from being infected. So the idea, here as well, that it will add a second ( 50% or other) protection has yet to be verified.
And the whole mask maths in this video relies on that...

Masks work only if you use them properly, if not, you just infect yourself (of others) with the collected germs. Might depend slightly on the type of mask as well. Also the tiny droplets that get through one mask can get easily through the second mask (and they do not need to, they can get into eyes or on clothing...).

And there are some other important aspects. Social distancing, washing hands. Most transmissions happen in families, at work, during parties. Sometimes in long distance public transport. And especially when people stay at close distance for a long time and do "stupid" things like kissing, sharing glasses...
On the other hand, the transmission rates in public transport (for trips below 10 minutes), in shopping malls or on the streets are extremely low.

Anyway I still think people are selfish, so, the responsible people should use high quality respirators in risky environment and the rest can roll the dice and hope they will not be in the 0.1-1% who get long term health issues or die.

Only well-designed HEPA masks protect the wearer.  The wearer's risk of exposure to virus-sized particles is not measurably reduced by regular face masks or multiple layers of cloth.  They DO reduce the range of high risk for OTHER people, however.  Since the rate of new infections is the product of infected people, N, and rate of transmission, R, and R is reduced by face masks, so does the number of new infections.  Since people recover after a few weeks and are no longer contagious, reducing R a little reduces new infections a lot.

even with no effect at the receiving end (wearer is not protected, only protects others from wearer) it quickly piles on in favor. For the sake of simplicity it will be a linear 1 interaction example with a 50% decrease in possible infection:

A is infected and interacts with B, since both have masks the possibility of B being infected is cut by 50%.

B interacts with C, again both are wearing masks so now C's possibility is dropped an additional 50% (25% from the start point).

C interacts with D, repeat and an additional drop (12.5% from the start point)

Obviously life isn't so nice and orderly. There would be multiple interactions and they can cross over amongst themselves (D could later interact with the still infected A) but it is a neat little peak at how a few fairly easy changes can bring a significant result.

Oh for anyone that this Koch’s Postulates are not no longer valid then actually read the research paper:

‘Amending Koch's postulates for viral disease: When “growth in pure culture” leads to a loss of virulence’

Koch’s Postulates requires the pathogen be isolated and grown in a cell culture, as this proves it can self replicate. Blaming the supposed virus doesn’t self replicate using our best modern research techniques proves it doesn’t self replicate!

Abstract
‘but passaging in cell culture attenuates these viruses to the extent that do not cause any measurable disease in nonhuman primates.’

Introduction

‘a virus is deliberately “adapted” to a new host, such as mice, through sequential passage from animal to animal.’

What has this got to do with Koch’s Postulates?
An unnecessary step to then blame for not being able to use Koch’s Postulates.

This papers authors need to be informed of what Koch’s Postulates are:

1.) The microorganism must be found in abundance in all organisms suffering from the disease, but should not be found in healthy organisms.

2.) The microorganism must be isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture.

3.) The cultured microorganism should cause disease when introduced into a healthy organism.

4.) The microorganism must be reisolated from the inoculated, diseased experimental host and identified as being identical to the original specific causative agent.

Every research paper I have read has had loads of excuses why they can not meet these 4 simple requirements to prove viruses self replicate and cause the disease like this case study:

2. Case study - hantavirus infection in nonhuman primates

‘Several attempts to experimentally recreate the clinical features of HFRS in NHPs demonstrated that a variety of species were susceptible to infection, but did not develop overt signs of disease.’

‘Hantaviruses are notoriously difficult to isolate from the reservoir hosts or diseased humans...’

‘Interestingly, when re-introduced into laboratory-reared bank voles, the Vero-propagated PUUV was unable to reliably establish infection.’

So if you actually read the paper, the authors even admit they can’t meet Koch’s Postulates with multiple supposed viruses and even fail for cause the supposed diseases!

‘Host cells are required for the propagation of viruses. This propagation inevitably results in a mixed population of viruses.’

‘While it is often assumed that the starting and final virus populations are the same, in fact there is always some degree of genetic change resulting from “adaptation” to the cultured cells.’

This proves that we are not able to isolate a supposed virus, grow it, prove it self replicated, then inoculate a healthy host and then re-isolate it and prove it’s the same as the first isolated sample.

Basically this paper clearly explains we can not meet Koch’s Postulates but has a good try at making up loads of excuses why.

Preface, I still think everyone should be wearing a mask.

However, you still left out a huge caveat to mask effectiveness, and its a misunderstanding of the purpose of the masks. Looking at surgical style masks since they're fairly common, their purpose is to catch arosolised saliva. This function is really only accomplished when the mask is worn by the source. If you have a leaking pipe, do you put the patch on the leaking pipe? Or on whatever it is you don't want to get water damaged?

This is because the mask doesn't catch everything coming at the wearer. The video assumes the placement of the mask doesnt matter if theres only 1, but it actually makes a huge difference. In a sick / healthy contact where only one person is wearing a mask, theres a lower chance of transmission if the sick person is wearing the mask than if the healthy person is. This is because if the sick person is the one not wearing the mask, they're still spraying infections microdroplets of saliva on you (the healthy person) when they speak. Then, when you later inadvertently touch your face or go to eat or something afterwards, you end up ingesting those microdroplets anyway and the mask has done nothing to protect you.

However, if the sick person is wearing the mask, a majority of those microdroplets will get caught in their mask and not end up on you. Then, when you end up ingesting the microdroplets that did end up on you, your immune system has a much lower viral load to deal with and thus a much better chance at keeping you from getting sick.

This is exactly what people forget about. Yes, masks can help to protect yourself but the whole point of wearing them is to prevent OTHERS from contracting COVID-19.  The best way to think of this is; What if you had contracted COVID-19 without realizing it yet? Might as well wear a mask to protect others from yourself so that they have that lower chance of COVID-19 action.

It gets even more complex when you consider the exponential nature of a spreading disease.

If the infection rate is 2, every person infected infects 2 others, then after 10 cycles, that's 1000 people infected.

If everyone wore a crappy 25% effective one-way mask that would drop the infection rate down to 1.5. In 10 cycles that would be 58 people.

A "crappy" mask that only prevents 25% means a 17 times lower total infections.

THAT'S why masks are important.

I don't want to turn this into a political argument, again, it's insane to me that it even IS a political argument, we should be able to speak the facts, and institute policy that protects public health, without even disclosing our political affiliation. But since it has become a political argument I have valid criticisms of both sides and how they have handled this. First, the president hasn't been an effective leader in this crisis. And if he had been then I think it wouldn't even be all that political. He would always have his critics of coarse, but I think it wouldn't be nearly as polarizing as it has been if he had just advised people to wear masks, wash hands, and social distance from the beginning, and listened to his experts in his own administration to handle it properly. That said, and I'm trying to be delicate here, and give as much of the benefit of the doubt (I could be much harsher in my criticisms, but I don't want to feed into that). On the other hand, I've seen incredibly hyperbolic criticisms of the president from the other side, saying he's personally responsible for EVERY death. I think that is pretty unfair to make those accusations. Covid-19 would have come to the US anyway. It would have infected people. And people would have still died. And that's even if the president had done everything right from the outset. EVERY nation on Earth has had to deal with this virus. EVERY country on the planet has been impacted in one way or another. Placing blame solely on the president is very irresponsible, and acting in a purely partisan way during and election year.

I don't have a side in this conflict. I'm not pro any politician. I'm not saying who to vote for. And I've tried to refrain from saying who I intend to vote for, or not vote for. I think both sides have not handled things well, though perhaps in different ways. I think both sides have things they have said, or done, that has not helped us at all. And that includes blaming the other side, as well as whatever actions have been taken, or not taken. Maybe you disagree with that statement, but if we are being honest with ourselves, then we know this deep down.

So let's first, set politics aside, and beat Covid together. We have the power to eliminate the virus and return to some kind of normalcy. Perhaps not completely, the world has changed in some ways that we can't go back on. And perhaps this thing will make us more mindful of other infectious diseases, such as the seasonal flu, which also claims many lives every year. But perhaps we can make Covid a thing of the past.

Second, let's admit that no side is completely right. If anyone is trying to spread FUD (fear, uncertainty, doubt) we should not listen to them. If they are speaking sane and logical facts, and they are encouraging us to work together beyond political boundaries, then we should listen to that.

And above all of that, even if you can't get behind the idealism, even if you have disagreed with the majority of what I've said; if a business or a city or an organization has asked people to wear masks, we should wear them. We shouldn't be trying to find ways to get out of it. We shouldn't try to push back on it. We shouldn't assume they are part of some political agenda. We should just comply and wear masks to help protect the other people, the workers, and public officials we are interacting with. We should try to keep ourselves healthy, and protect our own families. Even if you don't think you will get sick, or you think you won't show any symptoms, how would you feel if you unwittingly passed it on to a loved one? A friend? A co-worker? Someone at the grocery store? What if that person had to go to the hospital? What if they had to be intubated (it's not pleasant, and can cause lasting damage)? What if they ended up dying from it? Let's not turn each other into enemies. Let's not spite each other. Let's instead think of those who could be impacted and hurt by our carelessness. Or even we ourselves could be impacted by it.

And let's not assign blame to others. Either getting mad that people are wearing masks, or that people aren't wearing masks. These people are not our enemies. They are our neighbors. Our community. Our friends. Our family. They are our fellow countrymen and women. We are all in this together. Let's be kind to each other. Let's be respectful of each other. And let's help each other out.😷💧👏

You are making a mistake. Aerosolized coronavirus sars-cov-2 size is about 0.1 micrometer. Cloth masks normalized by French AFNOR filters 90% of particules greater than 3 micrometers so 0% of the aerosolized virus. Surgical masks don't have electrostatic layer, so the filtration of the virus will be from 0% to 30% at best. So yes, the mask is useful to block the virus in mucus, especially the surgical mask because it is design to block the liquid flow. But otherwise it is pretty useless. KN95 is nice but you need headbands to have a good seal on the face and a good filtration.

Overall your math is over optimistic.

Some ideas to ponder:
- most people aren't infected, even when the pandemic is "full on". That reduces your "math" because they aren't sending anything to see a "50%" reduction.
- 50% is easy math but misleading, masks aren't that effective, but the casual viewer might reasonably assume you didn't pull that number out of thin air.
- masks encourage activity - no activity (i.e. going out, going to the store, so forth) ups virus transmission. Holland, for instance, found masks didn't help because of this (except on transit)
- masks encourage sick people to go behave normally - remember, none of this is needed if they just stay home, which should be the focus if 0% transmission is the goal
- in context of the overall transmission problem, home transmission is the primary means. Outbound transmission, except at loud speaking/singing/hugging events, is rare. For instance, transmission at a grocery store. So even if the "mask math" works, it's nibbling at a tiny part of the spread.
- masks have health effects on their wearers. Just yesterday I was at Home Depot, wearing a mask, and I couldn't read the fine print on a product. I took the mask off, and could (as I would expect). The mask was having some kind of physiological effect on me bad enough to affect my vision. For some this is significant physically. For others, mentally (anxiety and other disorders).

People with preexisting lung problems should discuss mask wearing concerns with their health care providers. So is it possible that wearing a face mask as part of social distancing can cause someone to build up so much carbon dioxide and get so little oxygen that they pass out, or worse? Carbon dioxide is a natural by-product of the body’s respiration process, something we all breathe in and out every day. How harmful can it be? In rare cases, it can actually be pretty dangerous, according to the National Institutes of Health (NIH). They say that inhaling high levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) may be life-threatening. Hypercapnia (carbon dioxide toxicity) can also cause headache, vertigo, double vision, inability to concentrate, tinnitus (hearing a noise, like a ringing or buzzing, that’s not caused by an outside source), seizures, or suffocation due to displacement of air.

Another, even bigger reason why they are more effective is how the gains of reducing transmission rate compound over time. If 100 infected people each infect 2.5 people, then in a couple weeks there are 250 infected people, after 2 months there are almost 4000 (assuming each “round” takes 2 weeks and existing patients are no longer infectious by the next round).

If that transmission rate is reduced by 44% to 1.65, then after 2 months those 100 original infections have led to 741 current infections. Still bad, but an overall gain of way more than 44%. Still, this is not enough to stop the spread.

If everyone wears a mask and the transmission rate is lowered 75% to 0.63, then after 2 months in this basic model there are only 15 active infections. If you just take the original number of 4000 and reduce it by 75%, that would imply 1000 active cases.

Something else to think about that makes masks even more effective: mask-wearing protection actually increases exponentially. If we assume one-way protection on masks and 100% of people wear masks with 50% efficacy, the first person only transmits to 50% of people they come into contact with. The second generation will transmit to 50% of their contacts, and so forth. If this continues ad infinitum, as we casually ignore the fact that people mix semi-randomly and repeatedly, this means that every generation before the current one that wore masks will mean the infection rate will be reduced to .5^n (n=current generation) of its original number.

Obviously epidemiology is a lot more complex and I'm willfully ignoring some very important facts for the sake of making a point, but the point remains true: as more people wear masks, the rate of infection does not go down linearly, but logarithmically. 50% of people wearing masks isn't 5 times more effective than 10% at slowing te spread of disease, but an order of magnitude more effective.

This is why Herd Immunity is so important, as each layer of protection creates an ever thicker wall between the disease and vulnerable individuals. Each layer reinforces every other layer, until we can totally wipe out diseases from existence outside of labs.

Except that people don't use them correctly. The masks collect the germs and then the people touch the masks and then the door knob. And masks (when used appropriately) are less help to the wearer than to society as a whole. If you are contagious, the mask stops the momentum of the germs and filter a bit. Intuitively I don't think masks can ever protect the wearer as much as they stop transmission from the user. This is because, while the mask acts on all the main places the virus can be shed from (basically nose and mouth), it can in theory infect via other avenues, such as the eyes, being a mucous membrane. Unless you have a full face shield, no normal mask protects the eyes. It can also just be picked up off the skin later if proper hygiene is not observed. Not saying masks aren't effective in protecting the wearer, but I don't think it would ever be 50% for both infected and infectee like we see in the video.

The assumption is wrong. The masks efficiencies are not at all equal. When you breath IN (inhale), that creates a pressure drop in the direction of the air flow. That means negative pressure at the mouth, so the mask will be "sucked in" to the face, sealing it on the face.
When you breath OUT (expel), the same pressure drop will create a positive pressure at the mouth. That will "push out" the mask from the face and leave the air with the virus go around. The more plies you put to that mask, more pressure drop, more you lose that seal. Adding a valve is even worse, because the valve lets out all the viruses.

So when you say "a mask is 50% effective" in actually means the best case scenario, when the person inhales. The efficiency on the exhale is close to zero.

Also, the filters don't work that way anyway. If a filter cannot trap particles under a certain size (viruses), adding two filters won't improve that performance. Given a certain particulate size, filters either work at about 90% efficiency or they don't work at all.

1. Masks might increase the transmission rate. The tools presented and the video does not allow for accounting on contexts, where people wearing masks, but making mistakes, are more contagious/contaminated more easily than people not wearing masks. Examples could include someone touching an infected object and then touching his mask, wearing the same mask multiple times, touching his face more often, because of the mask etc.

2. Masks might reduce the emission of infected particles, but that could mean nothing. As an analogy one can imagine a bedroom with millions of infectious mosquitos and being stung by only one is enough to get infected. Using a protection that reduce the number of mosquitos by 99% is useless, as there would still be about 10.000 mosquitos being able to circumvent the protection and sting you. So being exposed to e.g. 75% less infected particles might mean nothing, as these 25% are enough to infect you at the same rate as being exposed to 100%. We're making assumptions about reduced contagiousness on the basis of reduced particle exposure, where the mathematical relation between the two is likely nonlinear and might not even be continuous.

In real reality transmission can happen also through the eyes, and most of the time probably hands are involved, masks don't help in either of those cases.

So yeah, air transmission might be reduced more than we think by using masks *properly*, that doesn't mean total transmission is reduced more than we intuitively think.

I think i see the error in your math.

if the only way masks can be "more effective than you think" is to equally distribute them amongst the crowd, to get equal percentage of each type of mask interaction, then youre actually increasing transmission rates rather than reducing them.

If you only hang out with people wearing masks, all your interactions will be that 75% drop rather than a 50% one. If you only ever hang out with negative tested or not sick people, your interactions drop by 80% regardless of if you wear a mask or not, because usually the people who actually spread it are visibly contagious, or actively spreading it on purpose.

But theres something you, and everyone else in the world are ignoring.

Hand sanitizer. if everyone just washed their hands more often, with regular soap, or hand sanitizer in a pinch, it wouldnt matter if we wore masks or not. The airborne droplets of cough/water/mucous settle out of the air eventually, and onto objects, that means shelves and displays and handrails and doors and doorknobs and floors.

Dont touch the floor with your hands or your face, thats a 20% reduction. Dont touch hand rails, thats another 10%. cumulatively, if you add in hand washing with regular avoidance of those coughing or sneezing, you can cut your risk factor way lower than masks, and plus you dont run into things like increased carbon dioxide levels, or mask shortages, or glasses fogging, or masked riots, or political schemes determined to turn the world into a welfare state.

Just wash your hands, and dont touch your face in public, dont walk into peoples coughs or sneezes, and take care to wash your doorknobs etc at home. Couple that with avoiding anyone actively sick, or actively quarantining yourself or others, the masks can play little to no part and we can still beat it just by en mass cleanliness.

One important caveat was not addressed. The effectiveness of a mask varies with the size of the particles. The first "50% effective" mask will mostly block the particles it is most effective at blocking and let through the particles it is least effective at blocking. Those are going to be the same particles the second mask encounters, and it will probably also be bad at blocking them. In other words, the probability that the first mask prevents disease transmission is not independent of the probability that the second mask does (not even close). So the probabilities do not multiply like that.

50% effective doesn’t mean 50% less risk of getting infected or getting sick. 50% is just a lab measurement that doesn’t translate into the real world. Don’t be misled.

Every real world clinical study shows much lower percentages for the kind of masks that the public wears – with a 6% reduction in risk being the consensus figure from many clinical studies if less than a meter separates the two mask wearers for more than fifteen minutes. And 100% risk reduction occurs if there is more than two meters separating the parties or they spend less than fifteen minutes together (by the way, these are the two conditions monitored by government authorized COVID-19 tracking apps, and they are the present medical consensus about transmission of the relevant virus). Two meters is probably being extra safe since much of the world uses a one-meter rule.

Even clinical studies using expensive N95 masks show little improvement over the cheaper masks worn by the public (see below). The WHO complained at their media conference last week that residents of nations where the wearing of masks has been made mandatory are actually contributing to increased spread of COVID-19 in those nations due to complacency and too much trust in masks. Stay apart or stay home to be safe.

The best case found in any study is around 20% when just the infected person is wearing a mask, and about 5% when the just uninfected person is wearing a mask. 20% plus 5% won’t get you close to 75% (they get you to 24%). These were more intensive residential studies of people who were caring for a sick person rather than studies of casual public encounters where risk reduction is less or negligible.

The 20% figure above comes from the few largest droplets being blocked directly or from slowing down the velocity of the average passed-through droplet so that it falls to the floor in much less than a meter. The 5% figure comes from a few droplets getting tangled up in the fibers of the second mask. But if the tangled droplet then dries out, the virus particle that was riding on the droplet might just continue its journey into the lungs anyway. Don’t count on the second benefit since no studies actually support the guessed at 5% figure, most experts say to assume 0% benefit. A virus is an incredibly tiny thing that can often just pass freely through the fibers of any ordinary mask material (hence the need to use non-woven fabric masks). The smallest droplets or free-floating virus particles aren’t really stopped at all.

The 6% figure comes from this large study:

https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.04.01.20049528v1

Also of interest…

“Between September 23, 2008, and December 8, 2008, 478 nurses were assessed for eligibility and 446 nurses were enrolled and randomly assigned the intervention; 225 were allocated to receive surgical masks and 221 to N95 respirators. Influenza infection occurred in 50 nurses (23.6%) in the surgical mask group and in 48 (22.9%) in the N95 respirator group.”

https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/184819

One problem with this video (read this whole comment): You're defining "disease transmission" as essentially transmission of all air particles from one person to another. This means you are assuming that the amount of covid particles transmitted 1) drops linearly with a drop in air particulate transmission (which is reasonable) and 2) the chance someone remaining uninfected drops linearly with air particulate transmission. What if there is a threshold that says a person will get covid 90% of the time if only 50% of the air is transmitted. But then that suddenly drops to someone getting covid 30% of the time when only 25% of air is transmitted? This is the relationship that you can't assume is linear when looking at mask effectiveness. Now, as a video meant for the general (uneducated) public, it does a good enough job of demonstrating how masks are effective and SHOULD be worn (please everyone wear a mask), but i just had to point out this observation.

You are really glossing over one part of the equation here. Less than 2% of those wearing masks (outside of China and some other Asian countries) know how to wear them properly.

China has been so successful for a few key reasons:
1) The population is used to wearing masks because of smog and overcrowding in general. And they fear viruses more than the rest of the world.
2) They have actually taken the time to learn to wear masks properly and avoid cross contamination.
3) China's government is MUCH MUCH less "human rights" than pretty much the entire rest of the world. They will happily let a single person die if it saves others. No matter how that is achieved.

Now then, what if 100% wore masks that were 50% effective on their own. As in, if worn properly and they were the sole preventor of spread, they would be 50% effective.
You would assume that there would be a 75% spread prevention effectiveness... But nope, since only 2% (outside of China et al) know how to wear masks, the effective reduction would be 1.5% at that point.
Except we haven't even touched on the other parameter of just airborne spread... The virus actually has to become airborne for it to infect others.
Thus, wearing masks outside while maintaining 10 meters (30 feet) distance to others is not going to change a thing because the likeliness of you getting infected by airborne Covid-19 is practically non-existent.
It is only when you are in an enclosed space, especially with poor ventilation, that masks actually make a difference. And even worse are places where the virus can become aerosolized and thus linger in the air for much longer than a regular droplet of virus can.
Either way, that's why wearing masks in hospitals is a great idea... Because infected people are more likely to be there and even with good ventilation, there's a much higher concentration of airborne Covid-19 there.
The same goes for schools, child care etc. These tend to be really central points of disease transmission, Covid or no Covid.

The other major and ever present transmission method is that of contact. Which mask wearers really fail at in 98% of cases.
Usually, mask wearers wear gloves as well. But they touch the mask with their gloves, and they take off their gloves with their bare hands.
And when they administer hand spirits to clean their hands, they are touching the bottle with unclean hands and then put the bottle back in their bag with their cleaned hands... But now they've re-contaminated their hands via the bottle.
Then they touch their clothes that they've also contaminated with the virus without wearing their gloves so they are constantly moving the virus around all their personal items, including said mask.

Now then... Finally... Let's consider how deadly the virus actually is...
If you are under the age of 60 you may as well not even bother. The chance of you dying is abysmally small. You'd be better off getting infected and get a temporary (or permanent, the jury is still out on this one) immunity to the virus.
Learn to recognize when you are actually infected and do your damndest to not spread your infection to others. It's much easier to maintain a strict "no transmission" routine for 2-3 weeks than it is to try and do it for 6 months or more. Especially considering you have no idea how to actually wear that mask and gloves properly anyways.
And if you are infected, don't go anywhere near anyone above the age of 60 because they, unlike you, are QUITE likely to die from the disease and they really should consider taking a full course in how to prevent cross contamination in every aspect.

There is a very important part of the problem that I feel this video is missing. It only takes a single virus particle to infect an individual and masks are useless on their own.


Let's say 1000 virus particles are shed at any given moment through breathing. (It will actually be much more but let's role with it)

1000 VP - 50% = 500 VP
1000 VP - 50% - 50% = 250 VP

Now, reducing the amount would help when it comes to fighting off an invader that the body knows how to deal with, but we are talking about a new entity no immune system has seen before, so this leads us to this.

VP to infect = 1

Masks nix the shed radius, Social distancing keep people well out of others shed and frequent sanitation destroys the last remainder of the virus. That is the true way we can keep the virus spread under control until we have a safe vaccine with high availability.

Now for some actual facts and statistics: The only studies accepted as "proof" of something in the medico-scientific world are epidemiological studies and blinded clinical studies. Even good observational studies are not completely trusted unless they are backed up by clinical studies. Laboratory studies are not accepted as proof of anything at all, and computer models are the hack journalism of medical science.

Fact: There are no epidemiological or clinical studies that show mask-wearing by the general public is an effective measure against infectious viral diseases. Not a few. Not one. Zero.

Fact: There are a few decent observational studies out there (not hard to find, including a recent one for Covid-19) on mask-wearing by health-care workers. The studies usually address infection rates for different types of PPE or as compared with the general public. Not surprisingly, healthcare workers get infected at a much higher rate than the general public and, also not surprisingly, the type of PPE doesn't seem to make much difference.

So let's talk tropical medicine, in particular infectious diseases, my specialty (besides war-wound surgery) before I retired 17 years ago.

Lesson: Viral infectious diseases are spread by three means; vectors, direct contact, and inhalation. Vectors are unimportant in the spread of Covid-19, so we won't discuss that route of transmission.
Direct contact can be broken down into two subcategories: The orofecal route and self-contamination after contact with a fomite. A fomite is any object that has been contaminated by a pathogen. Door handles, money, pens, phones, and keyboards are all classic examples of fomites. The mask is a super-fomite. Additionally, as far as the orofecal route goes, the Covid-19 virus is shed in feces for much longer than by the respiratory tract.
Inhalation can also be divided into two subcategories: Inhalation of macroscopic particles and inhalation of aerosolised particles. Macroscopic particles quickly settle (creating fomites) and their inhalation has never been considered the most important means of transmission of respiratory infections. Obviously, if one is unlucky enough to be in the immediate presence of someone who coughs or sneezes, one can become infected by that route. But a person (also obviously) who is coughing or sneezing should not be in public at all; they are NOT protecting anybody else by wearing a mask.
As an aside, infectious respiratory diseases are called that because of the organs they affect, not because of their route of transmission.
As far as aerosolised particles go, they are NOT stopped by masks or respirators. Once again, observational studies point to this being true, and there are no epidemiological or clinical studies that show otherwise. There's an obvious reason for this in healthcare, office, and school settings: a sedentary human being breathes about 400 litres of air per hour. Not to burst anyone's bubble, but no mask created, whether it be cloth, surgical, or N95, can handle that debit. And walking can raise that debit more than fourfold. In an office setting, even with everyone wearing masks, one infected person can easily infect the rest of the staff simply by breathing. And don't forget that her mask is an incredibly efficient fomite. The microbes are not magically neutralised by the cloth. This is the probable reason why healthcare workers, in spite of being trained and having good PPE, get infected at higher rates than the general public.

Fact: Nobody in the general public knows how to wear a mask. In surgery we wear a mask for a very specific purpose: to keep from contaminating the patient's open wound with unsterile macroscopic droplets. There is no other reason. basically 10 minutes of looking at a hyper simplified view of disease control, and not looking any deeper because it sounds true.

If a microbe is stopped upon the material of a mask, the moist, humid environment becomes a petri dish that breeds disease. So assuming that a mask drops disease transmission by 50% was just something you assumed without any evidence. So lets assume that a mask INCREASES and not decreases disease transmission. Scientifically you have to examine this possibility, otherwise you're not examining everything objectively. So just using a superstitious assumption (e.g. pocket full of poseys) will always have a certain affect is unscientific.

A great example of this is the idea of someone holding a ladder for someone else that is climbing it. You would immediately assume that this can only work to improve safety and you would never look at the possibility that it makes things more dangerous. After the science is done though, there is evidence that holding a ladder increases the danger. So using what you might think to be self-evident is not the correct way to practice science.

So what should be the takeaway here? if a mask increases the exposure of people to microobes as compared to other measures, the it has the effect of making things worse. I don't think you can just multiply the mask's effectiveness, though. If anyone knows more about this, please correct me if I'm wrong:

I'd imagine that a mask mostly filters out larger droplets, while smaller droplets still pass through. So, after the first layer of mask, the concentration of large droplets is lower, so the effectiveness of the second mask is lower.
Secondly, a mask doesn't cover your eyes. You can exhale virions through nose and mouth, but you can inhale (get infected through) nose, mouth and eyes. I don't know what the contribution of each of these routes is to the total transmission, but it needs to be taken into account.
Finally, some proportion of the droplets 'caught' by the mask are actually redirected to the top/bottom of the mask. So they will still end up in the space you're in, and can still be inhaled by other people later (the "aerosol transmission" route).

That said, they definitely help significantly, but I think you're overestimating some of the numbers here.

I'm not against masks, both to combat covid and to just generally increase hygiene in crowded urban spaces.

However, I feel like this video did a fairly poor job of making the points it was trying to.

For one: As far as I'm aware, and please correct me if I'm wrong, direct aerosol transmission is only one infection vector, and only comprises a small percentage of actual infections. A much bigger issue is viral droplets landing on surfaces, being picked up by people's hands and then moved into their bodies via face-touching or eating.
For that route, a mask that reduces surface droplets by 50% won't necessarily even reduce the infection rate by 50%, since infectivity doesn't scale linearly with the numbers of viral particles. Though even if it did, that's still just 50%, not 75%.

For two, the whole 60-60-60 section was pretty poorly explained and confusing. Examples like that don't really help our understanding of the reality of covid math. There are a stupid number of possible factors that can increase or decrease the spread of both covid and other diseases, and focusing on just one with the aim of "beating covid" is misleading, though I understand the emotional appeal.
